articleContent.title: Chord: 6th in A# (Shape: C)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: 6th in A# (Shape: C)

## Brief Presentation
The 6th chord in A# is also known as the A#6 chord, and when using the C shape, it is played with the root note on the 3rd fret of the 5th string. This chord consists of the notes A#, C, F, and G, creating a rich and warm sound that can add color and complexity to a piece of music.

## Notes and Intervals
- A# (root)
- C (third)
- F (sixth)
- G (seventh)
  
## Musical Flavor and Genre
The A#6 chord, played with the C shape, has a sweet and soulful quality to it. It can evoke feelings of warmth and nostalgia, making it a popular choice in jazz, soul, and R&B music. This chord adds a lush texture to a progression and can be used to create a smooth and mellow atmosphere in a song.

## Songs
Here are three songs that use the A#6 chord played with the C shape:
1. **"Dream a Little Dream of Me" by The Mamas & The Papas** - This classic song features the A#6 chord in its dreamy and romantic arrangement.
2. **"Lovely Day" by Bill Withers** - The A#6 chord in this soulful tune adds a touch of sophistication and warmth to the chord progression.
3. **"Don't Know Why" by Norah Jones** - The A#6 chord played with the C shape can be heard in the smooth jazz sound of this popular song.
